title: Preliminary Japanese Radiation Checks
summary: Early fieldwork by Hiroaki Koide's team from Kyoto University measures gamma radiation and collects soil/water samples around Jadugoda uranium mines, finding elevated levels near mines and tailings ponds compared to background reference areas.

title: Koide Contamination Study Published
summary: Full peer-reviewed paper 'Radioactive contamination around Jadugoda uranium mine in India' published. Reports village doses near tailings ponds approximately 10 times higher than international public exposure limits (10 mSv/year vs. 1 mSv/year WHO guidance). Contamination around ponds is 10–100 times higher than reference locations.

title: IAEA/INIS Database Index
summary: International Atomic Energy Agency's INIS (International Nuclear Information System) database indexes Koide's Jadugoda contamination study, making the issue visible to global nuclear regulators and international scientific community.

title: Local Health Data Collection Begins
location: Villages within 2.5 km of Jadugoda uranium complex
summary: Indian Doctors for Peace and Development (IDPD), JOAR and partner organizations begin house-to-house health data collection in villages within 2.5 km of Jadugoda uranium mines. Survey of 2,118 households in study villages compared against 1,094 in reference villages 30–35 km away.

title: Black Magic of Uranium Narrative Framework
summary: Compiled version of IDPD/IPPNW health survey circulates under the title 'Black Magic of Uranium at Jadugoda: Study on health status of indigenous people around Jadugoda uranium mines in India'. This framing positions uranium harm as systemic injustice against tribal/Adivasi communities.
source: LAKA Database / Black Magic of Uranium Report

title: Half Life: Radioactive Waste in India Report
summary: Broader environmental report 'Half Life – Radioactive Waste in India' incorporates Jadugoda case alongside other uranium and nuclear waste sites. Positions Jadugoda within India's larger nuclear waste management failures and environmental justice discourse.

title: First Major Tailings Pipeline Rupture
summary: Historical records document pipeline ruptures in 1981, 1990s, and 2006. UCIL infrastructure failures become systematic pattern, with radioactive slurry entering homes, fields and local waterways.
source: Monthly Review Online / Multiple NGO reports

title: IPPNW Health Survey Results Published
location: Villages within 2.5 km of Jadugoda uranium complex
summary: Completed IPPNW/IDPD epidemiological health survey published. Finds significantly higher incidence of congenital deformities (birth defects), primary sterility (infertility), cancer, early deaths before age 62, and high pulmonary tuberculosis prevalence in proximity villages compared with reference villages 30–35 km away.
source: Dr. Shakeel ur Rahman / IPPNW Health Survey

title: Major Tailings Pipeline Rupture—Dungridih Village
summary: On 21 February 2008, a new tailings pipeline near Jadugoda bursts, spilling uranium mill tailings into Dungridih village and nearby areas. Radioactive sludge reaches homes, local creeks and farmland. Activists demand UCIL supply clean water until contamination is addressed.
source: Down to Earth / JOAR / NGO reports

title: Alpha Radiation Measurements in Subarnarekha River
summary: Scientific study measures elevated alpha particle radiation in Subarnarekha River water and groundwater wells in areas near Jadugoda uranium mine zone. Confirms contamination pathway from tailings ponds into drinking water sources.

title: Third Major Pipeline Rupture
summary: Another tailings pipeline rupture documented in 2010. Part of ongoing pattern of infrastructure failures documented as occurring in 2006, 2008, 2010, 2011, and 2014. Pattern indicates systematic maintenance and design inadequacies in UCIL waste management systems.
source: Multiple NGO documentation / Monthly Review Online

title: Fourth Major Pipeline Rupture
summary: Another significant pipeline rupture occurs in 2011. Continues established pattern of UCIL infrastructure failures releasing radioactive slurry into environment. Each incident reinforces concerns about inadequate tailings management and worker/community protection.

title: Uranium in Drinking Water—Dose Risk Study
summary: Scientific study using laser-induced fluorimetry measures uranium in drinking water near Jadugoda mining site. Estimates age-dependent dose and health risk from chronic ingestion for nearby residents, confirming long-term contamination pathway and health exposure.

title: Fifth Major Pipeline Rupture & Jharkhand High Court Takes Notice
summary: Final documented pipeline rupture in 2014 triggers substantial public concern. Following media reports of radioactive waste crisis, Jharkhand High Court takes suo moto (independent) cognizance of the situation, recognizing it as 'alarming' and threatening residents' 'right to life'. Court directs government to show cause.
source: Jharkhand High Court Records / Times of India

title: DIANUKE Radioactive Accident Alert
summary: International disarmament organization DIANUKE publishes urgent alert documenting radioactive accident in Jadugoda uranium mines, with detailed record of pipeline ruptures in 2006, 2007, 2010, and another incident in early 2015. Calls international attention to chronic infrastructure failures.

title: Times of India Reports: Radioactive Waste Crisis
summary: Reports that radioactive waste from three UCIL-owned uranium mines puts approximately 50,000 people at risk, primarily tribal communities. Coverage triggers suo moto cognizance by the Jharkhand High Court.
source: Times of India / Jharkhand High Court Records

title: India's Nuclear Industry Pours Its Wastes Into a River of Death and Disease
summary: Comprehensive investigative journalism documenting monsoon-season overflow of radiation storage ponds into the Subarnarekha River and groundwater. Finds contamination levels above WHO safety limits and widespread health impacts, including congenital deformities, cancer clusters, and infertility.

title: UCIL/DAE Official Response & Denial
summary: Following Times of India report, Department of Atomic Energy and UCIL issue official press release disputing radioactive waste crisis claims. Insist that uranium mining operations are within regulatory limits and do not pose health risk to population.

title: Jharkhand High Court Expert Committee Report & Recommendations
summary: Court-appointed expert committee submits recommendations including stronger fencing and security around tailings ponds, regular pipeline inspection, improved truck covering, public radiation data, and health awareness camps. Court directs UCIL to comply within a fixed timeframe.
source: Jharkhand High Court Judgement (2016) 07 JH CK 0119

title: Caravan Magazine Ground-Level Investigation
summary: Ground investigation finds continuing monsoon tailings overflow, dust storms carrying radioactive particles, and inadequate water management despite UCIL provisions. All three tailings ponds remain full, and UCIL extends the first pond as a 'fourth-stage' without clear design standards.

title: India Uranium Mines Radiate Disaster
location: Jadugoda, Bhatin, Chatikocha villages, Subarnarekha River basin
summary: Documents ongoing health impacts including congenital conditions in children, infertility, and TB-like illnesses. Confirms contaminated water from tailings ponds reaching tributaries of the Subarnarekha River and reiterates High Court concern that 50,000 people are at risk.
source: Beyond Nuclear International / India Water Portal

title: UCIL Water Supply Initiative for Affected Villages
summary: Following community mobilization, UCIL begins supplying treated water to communities outside company colonies using tankers. Supply is irregular and does not address contamination at the source, leaving many Adivasi communities dependent on unsafe water.

title: Government Regulatory Reports—AERB/DAE Annual Reports
summary: AERB (Atomic Energy Regulatory Board) and Department of Atomic Energy publish annual reports for 2019–2020 covering UCIL operations, uranium production, and claimed safety improvements. Reports emphasize monitoring systems and compliance but do not acknowledge independent health and contamination findings.
source: AERB Annual Reports 2019–2020 / DAE Annual Report 2019–20

title: Uranium in Groundwater Comprehensive Reviews
location: Pan-India uranium mining areas including Jadugoda
summary: Multiple peer-reviewed works on uranium in groundwater, radioactive releases from nuclear sector, and water quality assessments include detailed Indian case studies. Reviews confirm that uranium mining and milling are major contributors to environmental uranium loads and long-term exposure risks.

title: UCIL Environmental Statement 2022
summary: UCIL publishes Environmental Statement as of March 31, 2022. Company documentation of effluent treatment, water reclamation, and monitoring activities. Despite claims of compliance, independent studies continue to document contamination.

title: Environmental Injustice in India: Jadugoda Uranium Mining Cluster
location: Jadugoda cluster; six mines and two processing plants, East Singhbhum
summary: Synthesizes five decades of uranium mining impacts, including pipeline ruptures, worker exposure without dosimeters, radium contamination of drinking water, fish mutations, congenital deformities in livestock, and inadequate rehabilitation. Highlights systemic denial by UCIL, AERB, and central government.

title: Water Quality and Heavy Metal Contamination in the Subarnarekha River
location: Lower stretch of Subarnarekha River, West Bengal
summary: Geostatistical analysis classifies the river's water quality as moderate to very poor and finds toxic elements such as Pb, Cu, Ni, Cd, Fe, and Cr above safe limits. Establishes carcinogenic risk from chromium, lead, and cadmium and links contamination to anthropogenic sources, including upstream mining and processing.

title: Jal Jeevan Mission—Rural Water Supply Expansion
location: Jharkhand and affected uranium mining villages
summary: Ministry of Jal Shakti's Jal Jeevan Mission continues rural water supply initiatives. Some uranium mining-affected villages in Jadugoda region may be covered under broader rural water supply program, though specific radioactive contamination challenges are not separately addressed.

title: Long-Term Uranium Exposure Health Study
location: Jadugora uranium miners and their families
summary: Biomedical research article published documenting long-term uranium exposure effects on Jadugora miners. Associates high uranium in water and biological samples with symptoms including shortness of breath, anemia, and other hematologic/pulmonary health issues in occupational workers with chronic uranium contact.

title: India Water Portal: Radiation Risks Health Impact
summary: India Water Portal publishes 'Radiation Risks: Jadugoda's Uranium Mining Health Impact'. Explains ongoing community health effects and resident fear around unprotected tailings ponds. Residents describe chronic respiratory, skin, cancer, congenital and reproductive problems and psychological distress.

title: Exemption of Critical Minerals from EIA Public Consultation
location: India (national policy affecting uranium sites, including Jadugoda)
summary: Ministry of Environment, Forest and Climate Change exempts mining of critical, strategic, and atomic minerals from public consultation requirements under the EIA framework. Justified on national security grounds, the change removes a key avenue for affected communities to formally raise health and environmental concerns.
source: Ministry of Environment, Forest and Climate Change

title: National Critical Minerals Mission 2025 & Private Sector Uranium Mining Authorization
summary: India announces plans to end the state monopoly on uranium mining, allowing private companies to mine, import, and process uranium under the National Critical Minerals Mission 2025. Policy aims to reduce import dependence and expand nuclear energy, but introduces no new environmental or health safeguards specific to sites like Jadugoda.

title: India Continues to Ignore Indigenous Rights as Uranium Mining Expands
location: Jadugoda, Jharkhand; national uranium mining policy context
summary: Human rights analysis reports public doses averaging 2–3 mSv annually, above WHO's 1 mSv recommendation. Highlights the lack of continuous public radiation monitoring, unpublished BARC health surveys, and repeated denial of information requests on national security grounds, as well as failures to implement indigenous consent requirements.
